questions.vignette: Mr. Stein is considered one of the most conscientious supervisors in his division — he documents behavior with specific examples, avoids relying on memory alone, and uses a structured rating form with behaviorally anchored scales. A recent audit of his ratings, however, uncovered an unexpected pattern: his assessments of individual competency dimensions correlate almost perfectly with each other within each employee file. After interviewing Mr. Stein, the auditor learns that his evaluation process begins by forming a general sense of whether an employee 'owns their work,' and that this initial impression serves as a template from which he fills in all remaining ratings. Employees who score high on ownership tend to receive uniformly elevated profiles, and those who score low receive uniformly suppressed ones, even on dimensions where behavioral anchors should allow independent judgment.
questions.question: The rating pattern revealed by the audit is best described as which type of evaluative error?

options.A: Criterion contamination
options.B: Halo effect
options.C: Implicit personality theory bias
options.D: Acquiescence bias

option_explanations.A: Criterion contamination occurs when a performance criterion measure is systematically influenced by factors extraneous to the actual performance construct being measured, such as a supervisor knowing the predictor scores before rating. While Mr. Stein's ratings are contaminated by an irrelevant impression, criterion contamination is a measurement validity concept, not a rater bias category, and does not specifically describe one trait impression spreading across other dimensions.
option_explanations.B: The halo effect is defined by the generalization of a rater's impression of an employee on one salient trait — here, perceived ownership — to all other independent performance dimensions, producing near-perfect within-employee correlations across unrelated competencies. The audit finding of perfectly correlated dimension scores, traced back to a single initial impression, is the hallmark of this error even when behaviorally anchored scales are used.
option_explanations.C: Implicit personality theory bias refers to the rater's preconceived beliefs that certain traits naturally co-occur (e.g., someone who is extroverted must also be confident), leading to rating inflation or deflation based on inferred trait clusters. While this concept shares surface features with the halo effect, it specifically involves trait co-occurrence beliefs and is not distinguished by one anchor trait driving all other ratings after an initial global impression is formed.
option_explanations.D: Acquiescence bias refers to the tendency of respondents — typically in surveys or self-report measures — to agree with statements regardless of their content. It does not apply to supervisor performance ratings and does not describe the pattern of one trait impression systematically shaping ratings on unrelated performance dimensions.

questions.source_summary: Mr. Stein's tendency to prioritize an employee's willingness to take responsibility and give high or low ratings to them on other dimensions of job performance is an example of the halo error.
questions.vignette: A supervisor who oversees a team of eight completes detailed written evaluations twice a year. He is considered unusually thorough — he reviews project logs, consults peers, and uses a structured scoring sheet with distinct categories covering communication, accuracy, reliability, and initiative. Despite using separate scoring categories, an internal review finds that the scores within each employee's file cluster tightly together, as though each employee has a single underlying score rather than a distinct profile. When interviewed, the supervisor explains that he forms an early judgment about whether an employee truly 'owns their work,' and that this judgment shapes how he reads all subsequent evidence. An employee with perfect attendance, excellent technical output, but one notable incident of deflecting blame received below-average marks in every category. Another employee who stepped up during a team crisis — but whose actual output metrics were mediocre — received top scores across all areas.
questions.question: What evaluative error is most precisely illustrated by this supervisor's rating pattern?

options.A: Recency effect
options.B: Similar-to-me effect
options.C: Halo effect
options.D: Fundamental attribution error

option_explanations.A: The recency effect is suggested by the mention of specific incidents — a crisis response and a deflecting-blame episode — that appear to have outsized influence on ratings. However, the recency effect is about the timing of behavioral observations, not about one trait impression contaminating all separate rating categories. The distinguishing detail here is that all categories move together based on a single trait judgment, not that recent events are weighted too heavily.
option_explanations.B: The similar-to-me effect might seem plausible because the supervisor clearly values ownership and initiative — traits he may personally exhibit — leading him to rate employees who mirror this value more highly. However, the similar-to-me effect is specifically about demographic or attitudinal resemblance between rater and ratee, and does not explain why one trait judgment produces perfectly correlated scores across all unrelated performance dimensions.
option_explanations.C: The halo effect is the most precise explanation because the supervisor's single global impression of an employee's ownership — formed early and used as a template — systematically elevates or suppresses all subsequent ratings on independent dimensions, even when objective evidence contradicts those ratings. The tight within-employee clustering of scores across structurally distinct categories is the defining signature of halo error, distinguishing it from errors tied to timing or interpersonal similarity.
option_explanations.D: Fundamental attribution error is partially suggested by the supervisor's tendency to attribute one behavioral incident (deflecting blame) to the employee's character rather than situational factors, leading to broad negative conclusions. However, fundamental attribution error is a general social cognition concept and does not specifically predict that all separate performance dimension ratings will be uniformly elevated or depressed based on a single trait impression — the key feature that identifies this as the halo effect.

questions.source_summary: Survey feedback involves obtaining information on employee attitudes and opinions about important aspects of their work.
questions.vignette: A large manufacturing firm has been experiencing high turnover and declining morale. An I/O consultant recommends administering a structured questionnaire to all employees to assess their attitudes and opinions about supervision, communication, and working conditions. The results are then compiled, shared with management and work groups, and used as a basis for planning organizational change initiatives. The consultant emphasizes that sharing findings back to employees and involving them in interpreting results is a critical step in the process.
questions.question: Which organizational development intervention does this scenario most clearly illustrate?

options.A: Survey feedback
options.B: Team building
options.C: Process consultation
options.D: Action research

option_explanations.A: Correct. Survey feedback is an OD intervention in which data on employee attitudes and opinions are systematically collected via questionnaires, compiled, and fed back to organizational members to guide change planning. The scenario matches all defining features: a structured questionnaire, attitudinal data collection, and return of findings to employees and management.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Team building focuses specifically on improving interpersonal relationships, communication, and functioning within a defined work group, and does not involve the administration of organization-wide questionnaires to assess attitudes as a primary tool.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Process consultation involves a consultant observing and facilitating group and organizational processes (e.g., meetings, decision-making) in real time and helping members diagnose problems themselves; it does not center on questionnaire-based attitude assessment.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Action research is a broad cyclical OD model of diagnosing, planning, acting, and evaluating, within which survey feedback can be one tool. However, action research is the overarching framework, not the specific intervention; the scenario describes the distinct survey feedback method, which is a more precise answer.

questions.vignette: A regional hospital system experiencing communication breakdowns between frontline nurses and administration hires an OD consultant. Despite the fact that several nurse managers have recently completed leadership development training, the consultant administers a standardized questionnaire to all nursing staff asking about job satisfaction, communication quality, and perceived fairness of policies. The aggregated results are then presented to both nurse managers and frontline staff in structured meetings, where participants are encouraged to interpret the data and propose solutions together.
questions.question: The OD intervention the consultant is primarily employing in this scenario is best described as which of the following?

options.A: Needs assessment
options.B: Survey feedback
options.C: Sensitivity training
options.D: Job enrichment

option_explanations.B: Correct. Survey feedback involves collecting employee attitudinal and opinion data through questionnaires and systematically returning that information to organizational members—including both management and employees—to stimulate diagnosis and collaborative problem-solving. The structured questionnaire administration, aggregation of results, and shared group interpretation meetings are hallmark steps of this intervention.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Needs assessment is a diagnostic process used to identify gaps between current and desired performance or knowledge, often used to determine training requirements. While it may use questionnaires, needs assessment focuses on skill or knowledge deficits rather than broadly assessing employee attitudes and feeding results back to work groups as a change catalyst.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Sensitivity training (T-groups) is a group-based OD intervention designed to increase self-awareness and interpersonal sensitivity through unstructured group interaction and experiential feedback; it does not involve administering questionnaires to measure attitudes across the organization.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Job enrichment is a motivational job redesign strategy based on Herzberg's two-factor theory that increases the depth of a job by adding autonomy, skill variety, and meaningful tasks. It is an intervention applied to job design, not a diagnostic or data-feedback process involving questionnaire administration.

questions.vignette: Following a merger between two mid-sized technology companies, senior leadership notices significant resistance to new policies among employees from both legacy organizations. An external consultant conducts structured interviews and administers written instruments to gather data on employee perceptions of fairness, trust in leadership, and job security concerns. Notably, the consultant schedules a series of facilitated group sessions at which the compiled data are presented to employees and managers together—a step that leadership initially resisted but that the consultant insisted was essential. The consultant argues that without this sharing and discussion phase, the intervention will not produce sustainable change.
questions.question: The consultant's insistence on the data-sharing and group discussion phase is most consistent with which OD intervention?

options.A: Appreciative inquiry
options.B: Process consultation
options.C: Survey feedback
options.D: Intergroup development

option_explanations.C: Correct. Survey feedback is uniquely defined not only by data collection on employee attitudes but by the deliberate, structured return of compiled findings to both employees and managers in group settings for collaborative interpretation and action planning. The consultant's insistence that the sharing-and-discussion phase is non-negotiable for sustainable change is the defining signature of survey feedback as opposed to merely conducting an attitude survey.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Appreciative inquiry is an OD approach that focuses on identifying and amplifying organizational strengths and positive experiences rather than diagnosing problems or concerns; it uses positive-question protocols and storytelling rather than attitude measurement instruments focused on fairness concerns and resistance.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. Process consultation involves a consultant working alongside organizational members to observe and improve interpersonal and group processes (e.g., communication patterns in meetings) in real time. While the consultant in this scenario facilitates group sessions, the defining feature is the collection and structured feedback of attitude data, which is not central to process consultation.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Intergroup development is an OD technique designed specifically to reduce conflict and improve relations between distinct departments or groups within an organization, often through structured intergroup contact and negotiation activities. While a merger context might suggest intergroup issues, the described intervention centers on attitude data collection and structured feedback to work groups, not intergroup conflict resolution activities.

questions.source_summary: Survey feedback involves obtaining information on employee attitudes and opinions about important aspects of their work.
questions.vignette: A national retail chain's vice president of operations is concerned about stagnating productivity and asks an OD consultant to help. The consultant proposes a data-driven approach: employees at all levels will be asked to respond to standardized items about supervisory relationships, organizational communication, and workload equity. The consultant is careful to note that the value of this process lies not in what leadership does privately with the findings, but in what happens when those findings are brought back into the organization and discussed openly by the very people who provided the data. Skeptical supervisors argue that the firm would be better served by productivity tracking software and performance dashboards. The consultant counters that sustainable behavioral change in organizations requires that members themselves gain insight from collective reflection on shared data.
questions.question: The consultant's described approach most precisely reflects which organizational development method?

options.A: Organizational diagnosis
options.B: 360-degree feedback
options.C: Survey feedback
options.D: Action research

option_explanations.C: Correct. Survey feedback is distinguished from other data-collection approaches by the specific principle that attitudinal data collected from employees must be systematically returned to and discussed by those same employees and their supervisors to catalyze insight and voluntary change. The consultant's insistence that sustainable change requires collective reflection on shared data—rather than private managerial use of findings—is the hallmark of the survey feedback method, not merely organizational diagnosis or the broader action research cycle.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Organizational diagnosis refers to the broad process of gathering information to understand organizational functioning, problems, and needs; it encompasses many methods including surveys, interviews, and observations. It describes the diagnostic phase of OD work generally, not the specific intervention defined by the feedback-to-employees principle that the consultant is explicitly defending.
option_explanations.B: Incorrect. 360-degree feedback is a performance appraisal method in which individuals receive evaluative feedback from multiple sources (supervisors, peers, subordinates, self) about their own behaviors and competencies. While it involves data being returned to individuals, it focuses on individual performance development rather than collecting group-level attitudinal data and feeding it back to work groups for organizational change.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Action research is a cyclical, collaborative OD model encompassing stages of data gathering, feedback, joint diagnosis, action planning, implementation, and evaluation. Survey feedback can be a component within an action research cycle, but action research is the broader overarching framework. The consultant is describing a specific intervention—the feedback-to-members mechanism—that is the defining feature of survey feedback, not action research as a whole.

questions.source_summary: Survey feedback involves obtaining information on employee attitudes and opinions about important aspects of their work.
questions.vignette: A consultant hired by a struggling logistics company begins by distributing written forms to all employees asking them to rate their experience of day-to-day interactions with supervisors, how well information flows across the company, and how fairly they believe decisions are made. Critically, after tallying the results, the consultant does not simply hand a summary report to the CEO; instead, she schedules separate gatherings for each department where employees and their direct managers sit together, review the compiled responses from that group, and collectively decide what the numbers mean and what, if anything, should change. One department head argues that the meetings waste time better spent reviewing quarterly output metrics and individual performance records. The consultant insists the meetings are the most important part of the whole process, because insight and motivation to change come from people examining their own collective voice together, not from management being told what employees think.
questions.question: The consultant's method is best characterized by which of the following organizational development concepts?

options.A: Needs assessment
options.B: Survey feedback
options.C: Team building
options.D: Action research

option_explanations.B: Correct. Survey feedback is precisely defined by two sequential operations: (1) systematic collection of employees' attitudes and opinions via standardized instruments, and (2) the structured return of compiled findings to the employees who generated them—together with their managers—for joint interpretation and action planning. The consultant's insistence that the department meetings (not the CEO report) are the intervention's core mechanism is the single most specific indicator of survey feedback, distinguishing it from all alternatives.
option_explanations.A: Incorrect. Needs assessment focuses on identifying gaps in knowledge, skills, or performance to inform training or resource allocation decisions. Although it may employ written questionnaires, its output is directed toward determining what the organization requires, not toward returning attitudinal data to employees for collective sense-making and voluntary behavioral change.
option_explanations.C: Incorrect. Team building is an OD intervention aimed at improving trust, cohesion, communication, and effectiveness within a defined work group, typically through experiential exercises, structured reflection on group process, or conflict resolution activities. While the department meetings in this scenario could superficially resemble team building sessions, the defining feature is that the meetings are structured around reviewing systematically collected attitudinal data—the hallmark of survey feedback, not team building.
option_explanations.D: Incorrect. Action research is a broad, iterative OD framework in which data collection, feedback, collaborative diagnosis, action planning, and evaluation cycle continuously. Survey feedback can be embedded within an action research initiative. However, action research describes the overarching cyclical model, not the specific intervention; the distinguishing detail here—that the intervention's power resides in employees and managers jointly examining aggregated attitudinal data from their own group—points to survey feedback as the more precise and accurate answer.

questions.source_summary: There are two main types of integrity tests used for selection decisions: overt tests that ask directly about attitudes toward and history of dishonesty and theft, and personality-based tests that assess aspects of personality linked to counterproductive behaviors.
questions.vignette: A retail chain recently experienced significant inventory shrinkage due to employee theft. The HR director decides to add a pre-employment screening tool to the selection process. The new instrument asks applicants directly about their past theft behaviors, their attitudes toward employee theft, and whether they believe most employees steal from their employers. The HR director explains that this type of integrity test is specifically designed to identify applicants who are likely to engage in counterproductive behavior on the job.
questions.question: The HR director has implemented which specific type of integrity test?

options.A: Personality-based integrity test
options.B: Overt integrity test
options.C: Situational judgment test
options.D: Biographical data inventory

option_explanations.A: Personality-based integrity tests assess broad personality traits linked to counterproductive behaviors (e.g., conscientiousness, agreeableness) rather than asking directly about theft attitudes or histories. This instrument's direct questions about theft and dishonesty are inconsistent with the indirect measurement approach of personality-based tests.
option_explanations.B: Correct. Overt integrity tests directly ask about applicants' attitudes toward theft and their personal history of dishonest behaviors. The questions in this vignette — regarding past theft, attitudes toward employee theft, and perceptions of theft norms — are hallmark features of the overt integrity test format.
option_explanations.C: Situational judgment tests present applicants with hypothetical work scenarios and ask them to choose the best course of action. While they can assess judgment related to ethics, they do not directly ask about personal theft history or attitudes toward dishonesty, so they do not fit this scenario.
option_explanations.D: Biographical data inventories gather information about an applicant's past experiences, education, and life history to predict job performance. Although they may include some attitudinal items, they are not specifically designed to measure theft-related attitudes and behaviors as integrity tests are.

questions.source_summary: There are two main types of integrity tests used for selection decisions: overt tests that ask directly about attitudes toward and history of dishonesty and theft, and personality-based tests that assess aspects of personality linked to counterproductive behaviors.
questions.vignette: A logistics company with high turnover and ongoing problems with workplace misconduct hires an I/O psychologist to improve its hiring process. The psychologist recommends adding a standardized instrument that measures traits such as conscientiousness, emotional stability, and impulse control, rather than asking applicants directly about rule-breaking or theft. The company's legal team notes that applicants who score low on these traits are statistically more likely to engage in counterproductive work behaviors. The psychologist argues this approach to selection will reduce misconduct while being less face-threatening to applicants than asking about personal dishonesty.
questions.question: The instrument recommended by the psychologist is best described as which type of tool?

options.A: Overt integrity test
options.B: Structured behavioral interview
options.C: Personality-based integrity test
options.D: Assessment center exercise

option_explanations.A: Overt integrity tests directly ask applicants about their attitudes toward theft and their personal history of dishonest acts. The instrument described here does not ask directly about rule-breaking or theft, so it cannot be classified as an overt integrity test, even though both serve selection purposes.
option_explanations.B: Structured behavioral interviews ask applicants standardized questions about past behavior in work-relevant situations to predict future performance. While they can touch on integrity-related situations, they are interviewer-administered oral assessments, not standardized written instruments measuring personality traits linked to counterproductive behavior.
option_explanations.C: Correct. Personality-based integrity tests assess broad personality traits — such as conscientiousness, emotional stability, and impulse control — that research links to counterproductive work behaviors. Critically, they measure these traits indirectly rather than asking directly about theft or dishonesty, which matches the instrument described in this vignette.
option_explanations.D: Assessment centers are multi-method evaluation processes that typically include simulations, in-basket exercises, and role plays scored by trained assessors. They are not single standardized instruments measuring personality traits, and they are far more resource-intensive than what is described in this scenario.

questions.source_summary: There are two main types of integrity tests used for selection decisions: overt tests that ask directly about attitudes toward and history of dishonesty and theft, and personality-based tests that assess aspects of personality linked to counterproductive behaviors.
questions.vignette: A national pharmacy chain is revising its employee selection battery after consulting with an I/O psychologist. The psychologist recommends two separate instruments: one that includes items asking applicants whether they have ever taken merchandise from a previous employer without permission, whether they think employees who steal 'small items' should be fired, and how often they believe coworkers take company property. A second instrument, by contrast, contains no questions about dishonest behavior and instead measures traits such as dependability and conscientiousness using items about general work habits and interpersonal tendencies. The legal department is concerned about applicant reactions and potential adverse impact for both instruments.
questions.question: The first instrument described in this scenario is best classified as which of the following?

options.A: Personality-based integrity test
options.B: Overt integrity test
options.C: Biodata inventory
options.D: Conditional reasoning test

option_explanations.A: Personality-based integrity tests are the instrument described second in the vignette — they measure traits like dependability and conscientiousness without asking directly about dishonesty. The first instrument's direct questions about personal theft and theft-related attitudes clearly distinguish it as overt, not personality-based, even though both serve integrity assessment purposes.
option_explanations.B: Correct. The first instrument is an overt integrity test. Its defining features are explicit questions about personal theft history (e.g., 'Have you ever taken merchandise without permission?'), attitudinal items about theft (e.g., whether stealing small items warrants termination), and perception-of-norm items (e.g., how often coworkers steal) — all hallmarks of the overt format.
option_explanations.C: Biodata inventories collect structured life-history information to predict job performance and typically include questions about education, work history, and past achievements. Although some biodata items can concern past behavior, they are not specifically organized around theft attitudes and dishonesty history the way overt integrity tests are.
option_explanations.D: Conditional reasoning tests are a more recently developed selection tool that uses seemingly neutral reasoning problems to indirectly measure aggressive or antisocial reasoning tendencies. Unlike the first instrument described, conditional reasoning tests do not ask directly about theft or dishonest attitudes and are designed to avoid transparent face-valid measurement of counterproductive tendencies.

questions.source_summary: There are two main types of integrity tests used for selection decisions: overt tests that ask directly about attitudes toward and history of dishonesty and theft, and personality-based tests that assess aspects of personality linked to counterproductive behaviors.
questions.vignette: An HR consultant is reviewing the selection battery used by a large grocery chain that has experienced both theft and absenteeism problems. She examines an instrument that contains items such as, 'I always follow the rules even if no one is watching,' 'I often act on impulse before thinking things through,' and 'I believe that bending company policy is sometimes acceptable.' The consultant notes that on its surface, the instrument looks like a standard personality questionnaire measuring conscientiousness and impulse control, but the manual explicitly states it was developed and validated to predict workplace deviance and rule-breaking rather than broad personality taxonomy. The consultant is deciding how to categorize this instrument within her written report on the company's use of integrity testing.
questions.question: Based on the description of this instrument, how should the consultant classify it in her report?

options.A: Overt integrity test, because the items address rule-following and policy violations directly
options.B: General personality inventory, because the items measure conscientiousness and impulse control
options.C: Personality-based integrity test, because it uses trait-focused items validated specifically to predict workplace deviance
options.D: Situational judgment test, because it asks respondents to evaluate acceptable behavior in workplace scenarios

option_explanations.A: Overt integrity tests are defined by direct, face-valid questions about personal dishonesty history and explicit attitudes toward theft — items such as 'Have you ever stolen from an employer?' The items described here, while workplace-relevant, do not directly ask about theft history or attitudes toward dishonesty, so overt classification is incorrect despite superficial overlap.
option_explanations.B: General personality inventories (such as measures of the Big Five) are developed to map broad personality taxonomy and are not specifically validated against workplace deviance criteria. The key distinguishing detail here is the manual's explicit statement that the instrument was developed and validated to predict workplace deviance — this targeted validation criterion places it in the integrity testing category, not general personality assessment.
option_explanations.C: Correct. Personality-based integrity tests use trait-focused items — including those measuring conscientiousness, impulse control, and rule-compliance — but are specifically developed and validated to predict counterproductive and deviant work behaviors rather than to map broad personality structure. The manual's stated purpose of predicting workplace deviance is the critical detail that confirms this classification over a general personality measure.
option_explanations.D: Situational judgment tests present applicants with written scenarios depicting workplace dilemmas and ask them to select or rate possible responses. The instrument described contains attitudinal and self-report trait items, not behavioral scenario vignettes asking respondents to judge actions — so situational judgment test classification does not apply here.

questions.source_summary: There are two main types of integrity tests used for selection decisions: overt tests that ask directly about attitudes toward and history of dishonesty and theft, and personality-based tests that assess aspects of personality linked to counterproductive behaviors.
questions.vignette: A hiring manager at a distribution center is reviewing two pre-hire questionnaires provided by an outside testing vendor. The first questionnaire asks respondents whether they consider themselves rule-followers at work, whether they tend to act before thinking, and whether they find it easy to resist peer pressure to cut corners — items that look nearly identical to questions from a widely used measure of a broad, stable human trait often associated with academic and professional success. The second questionnaire asks respondents whether they have ever helped themselves to items from a workplace without asking, how they feel about coworkers who take small supplies home, and how common they believe such behavior is among employees in general. The vendor recommends the second questionnaire for roles with significant cash-handling responsibilities, noting that research on both tools shows similar predictive validity for problematic on-the-job conduct.
questions.question: How should the second questionnaire be classified within the taxonomy of pre-employment screening tools designed to reduce workplace misconduct?

options.A: Personality-based integrity test, because it predicts problematic workplace conduct similar to the first questionnaire
options.B: General cognitive ability test, because research links impulse control and decision-making to cognitive functioning
options.C: Overt integrity test, because it directly asks about personal histories of taking items and attitudes toward such behavior
options.D: Structured behavioral interview, because it asks about past behaviors and perceived norms in workplace settings

option_explanations.A: Personality-based integrity tests, like the first questionnaire, use trait-focused items that appear similar to general personality measures and infer counterproductive tendencies indirectly. The second questionnaire, however, directly asks about personal theft history and attitudes toward theft — a defining feature of overt integrity tests that rules out personality-based classification, despite both predicting workplace misconduct.
option_explanations.B: General cognitive ability tests measure reasoning, problem-solving, and learning potential using tasks such as verbal analogies or numerical problems — not self-report attitudinal items. Neither questionnaire described contains cognitive task items, and predictive validity for workplace misconduct does not transform attitudinal self-report instruments into cognitive ability measures.
option_explanations.C: Correct. The second questionnaire is an overt integrity test. Its three defining features are all present: a question about personal theft history ('Have you ever helped yourself to items without asking?'), an attitudinal item about employee theft ('How do you feel about coworkers who take small supplies home?'), and a perception-of-norms item ('How common do you believe such behavior is?'). These direct, face-valid questions about dishonesty and theft are the hallmarks of overt integrity testing, distinguishing it from the first questionnaire's indirect, trait-focused approach.
option_explanations.D: Structured behavioral interviews are standardized, orally administered procedures in which an interviewer poses scripted questions about past work behaviors and scores responses using anchored rating scales. The second questionnaire is a written self-report instrument, and while it includes questions about past behavior and perceived norms, it lacks the oral administration format and trained-rater scoring that define structured behavioral interviews.

questions.source_summary: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is a worker-oriented job analysis tool that addresses six categories of work activity: information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics.
questions.vignette: An I/O psychologist is hired by a large manufacturing firm to conduct a job analysis across all production roles. She selects a worker-oriented instrument that uses standardized, pre-existing elements to describe work behaviors rather than listing tasks unique to each position. The instrument she chooses organizes its items into six major divisions, including information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics. Because the tool produces comparable data across very different jobs, the HR team plans to use the results to support compensation decisions across the entire organization.
questions.question: Which job analysis instrument is the psychologist most likely using?

options.A: Functional Job Analysis (FJA)
options.B: Critical Incidents Technique (CIT)
options.C: Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ)
options.D: Occupational Information Network (O*NET)

option_explanations.A: Functional Job Analysis is a worker-oriented approach developed by Sidney Fine that rates workers on their interaction with data, people, and things, but it does not use the specific six-division structure described. FJA focuses on functional levels rather than the standardized behavioral elements organized into six categories characteristic of the PAQ.
option_explanations.B: The Critical Incidents Technique involves collecting specific examples of effective and ineffective behavior from incumbents or supervisors, making it a qualitative, task-oriented method. It does not produce a standardized questionnaire with pre-defined categories comparable across jobs.
option_explanations.C: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is the correct answer. It is a standardized, worker-oriented instrument specifically organized into six divisions — information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics — and is widely used for cross-job compensation comparisons.
option_explanations.D: O*NET is a comprehensive online database of occupational information sponsored by the U.S. Department of Labor that includes both worker- and work-oriented descriptors. While broad and cross-job comparable, it is a database resource rather than a structured questionnaire with the specific six-category structure that defines the PAQ.

questions.source_summary: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is a worker-oriented job analysis tool that addresses six categories of work activity: information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics.
questions.vignette: A consultant is brought in to help a mid-size financial services company revise its compensation structure. Despite working with employees ranging from data entry clerks to senior analysts — roles that differ substantially in their specific tasks — the consultant notes that the chosen instrument still allows meaningful comparison across all of them because it focuses on underlying human work behaviors rather than job-specific tasks. The instrument organizes its items into six broad categories and uses a rating scale to quantify each element. The consultant is a recent graduate and mentions in passing that she found the instrument somewhat dated compared to newer systems, though she acknowledges its psychometric strengths.
questions.question: Which job analysis method is the consultant most likely using?

options.A: Task Inventory Analysis
options.B: Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ)
options.C: Fleishman Job Analysis Survey (F-JAS)
options.D: Threshold Traits Analysis (TTA)

option_explanations.A: Task Inventory Analysis is a work-oriented method that produces job-specific lists of tasks rated by incumbents on dimensions such as frequency and importance. Because it is task-specific, it does not readily allow cross-job comparisons across very different roles, distinguishing it from the worker-oriented, six-category instrument described.
option_explanations.B: The Position Analysis Questionnaire is correct. It is a standardized, worker-oriented instrument organized into six categories that measures underlying human work behaviors rather than job-specific tasks, enabling cross-job comparison — exactly as described. Its occasionally cited limitation of feeling dated relative to newer platforms aligns with the consultant's comment.
option_explanations.C: The Fleishman Job Analysis Survey (F-JAS) is a worker-oriented tool that measures 52 cognitive, psychomotor, physical, and sensory-perceptual ability requirements, rating the level of each ability needed for a job. While it allows cross-job comparison, it is organized around ability taxonomies rather than six behavioral work categories, making it a poor fit for the six-category detail in the vignette.
option_explanations.D: Threshold Traits Analysis is a worker-oriented instrument developed by Lopez that identifies 33 worker traits required for job performance. Although it allows cross-job comparisons and focuses on worker characteristics, it does not use the specific six-category organizational structure that defines the PAQ.

questions.source_summary: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is a worker-oriented job analysis tool that addresses six categories of work activity: information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics.
questions.vignette: An HR director at a hospital system wants to evaluate all clinical and administrative roles using a single instrument so that she can build a unified pay-grade structure. She selects a well-validated, standardized questionnaire that focuses on what workers do in general behavioral terms — such as how they receive information, what cognitive operations they perform, and the physical and social conditions under which they work — rather than cataloguing the specific medical or clerical duties of each role. Critics within the team argue that the instrument's reading level is high and that its items may feel abstract or irrelevant to lower-skilled workers like dietary aides and housekeeping staff. The HR director acknowledges this limitation but proceeds because the instrument's ability to compare jobs across an entire organization outweighs its drawbacks for this project.
questions.question: Which job analysis instrument best fits the approach described?

options.A: Occupational Information Network (O*NET)
options.B: Work Profiling System (WPS)
options.C: Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ)
options.D: Fleishman Job Analysis Survey (F-JAS)

option_explanations.A: O*NET is a government-sponsored database that aggregates occupational information across hundreds of descriptors covering both worker and work characteristics. Although it enables cross-job comparison and covers broadly similar domains, it is a web-based database rather than a single standardized questionnaire administered within an organization, and it does not share the PAQ's specific six-category structure or the documented concern about reading level for lower-skilled workers.
option_explanations.B: The Work Profiling System (WPS) is a computerized, worker-oriented job analysis instrument developed by SHL that produces ability-requirement profiles. While it allows cross-job comparison, it is organized around Fleishman ability taxonomies rather than the six behavioral work categories of the PAQ, and the specific criticism about reading level and abstraction for lower-skilled workers is a recognized limitation of the PAQ specifically.
option_explanations.C: The Position Analysis Questionnaire is correct. It examines work in broad behavioral terms across six categories and is specifically known for its high reading level requirement (approximately college grade) and its documented challenge when applied to lower-complexity roles. Its primary advantage — cross-job comparability for compensation decisions — precisely matches the HR director's rationale.
option_explanations.D: The Fleishman Job Analysis Survey measures required ability levels across 52 taxonomic ability dimensions. It does enable cross-job comparison and takes a worker-oriented stance, but it focuses on ability requirements rather than describing what workers do in terms of information input, cognitive operations, or social and physical work context, making it a less precise fit for the scenario described.

questions.source_summary: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is a worker-oriented job analysis tool that addresses six categories of work activity: information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics.
questions.vignette: A large retail chain asks a consulting firm to study all roles — from warehouse pickers to regional managers — using a single instrument so that salary grades can be aligned across the organization. The consulting team selects a tool in which incumbents rate pre-written behavioral statements on multiple scales, including the extent to which each element applies to the job and how important it is. When the warehouse workers complete the instrument, several supervisors report that some items feel disconnected from daily duties, and one incumbent jokingly remarks that answering the questions requires more reading than his actual job does. Despite these reactions, the consulting team argues that the instrument's quantitative output and cross-job generalizability make it the best choice for a single, organization-wide compensation study.
questions.question: Which instrument is the consulting team most likely using, and why is it particularly well-suited to this application despite its noted limitations?

options.A: The Occupational Information Network (O*NET), because it is publicly available and provides cross-occupational comparison data validated on national samples
options.B: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ), because it is a standardized worker-oriented instrument whose behavioral element ratings yield quantitative scores that are directly comparable across dissimilar jobs for compensation purposes
options.C: The Fleishman Job Analysis Survey (F-JAS), because its ability-requirement ratings can be aggregated across organizational levels and translated into compensation-relevant competency profiles
options.D: The Common Metric Questionnaire (CMQ), because it was explicitly designed to overcome the readability limitations of older worker-oriented tools while still enabling cross-job salary comparisons

option_explanations.A: O*NET is a database of occupational descriptors intended for broad workforce and career planning purposes at the occupational level. It is not administered as an incumbent-rated questionnaire within individual organizations, and its data are collected nationally rather than customized to a specific organization's job structure — making it poorly suited to an internally administered, organization-wide compensation study.
option_explanations.B: The PAQ is correct. Its defining feature is the use of standardized behavioral elements rated by incumbents across multiple scales (e.g., applicability, importance), which produce quantitative scores comparable across very different job families — precisely the property needed for an organization-wide compensation study. The noted reading-level difficulty for lower-skilled workers and the sense that items feel disconnected from specific tasks are well-documented, recognized limitations of the PAQ specifically.
option_explanations.C: The Fleishman Job Analysis Survey is a worker-oriented instrument that rates the level of 52 abilities required per job and can be used cross-organizationally. However, it is organized around ability taxonomy rather than behavioral work elements rated on applicability and importance, and it is not specifically associated with the high reading-level complaint or the organization-wide compensation application that are defining features of the PAQ.
option_explanations.D: The Common Metric Questionnaire (CMQ) was indeed developed partly in response to the PAQ's high reading level, making it a highly plausible distractor. However, the CMQ, while also worker-oriented and cross-job comparable, is less well-established as the dominant instrument for organization-wide compensation studies compared to the PAQ, and the scenario's specific description of incumbent-rated pre-written behavioral statements with applicability and importance scales — combined with the reading-level criticism — fits the PAQ more precisely than the CMQ.

questions.source_summary: The Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ) is a worker-oriented job analysis tool that addresses six categories of work activity: information input, mental processes, work output, relationships with other people, job context, and other characteristics.
questions.vignette: A large organization wants to compare the requirements of dozens of very different roles using one instrument so that it can set salaries consistently. The chosen tool presents workers with a set of pre-written statements describing general human activities — such as how a person takes in information, what they think about, what they physically do, who they interact with, and the conditions they work under — and asks them to rate each statement on how much it applies to their role and how central it is to the work. When the instrument is used with employees in physically demanding, lower-skill positions, several of them struggle to complete it and comment that the questions seem more suited to an office setting. Despite this, the organization's compensation analysts favor the tool precisely because its output is numerical and uniform, allowing them to slot every role — from machine operator to vice president — into the same salary grid without redesigning the instrument for each position.
questions.question: Which job analysis instrument is most consistent with the approach described?

options.A: Task Inventory Analysis, because it collects incumbent ratings on the frequency and importance of specific job tasks and can be aggregated across roles to support compensation decisions
options.B: Functional Job Analysis (FJA), because it rates workers on their level of involvement with data, people, and things and is designed to yield scores comparable across a wide range of jobs
options.C: Position Analysis Questionnaire (PAQ), because it is a standardized instrument built around general human work behaviors rated on applicability and importance, producing quantitative scores that enable cross-job salary comparisons despite known limitations for lower-complexity roles
options.D: Common Metric Questionnaire (CMQ), because it was designed to provide cross-job behavioral ratings similar to older worker-oriented tools while addressing the readability concerns associated with those tools

option_explanations.A: Task Inventory Analysis collects ratings from incumbents on job-specific task statements, making it work-oriented rather than worker-oriented. Because each inventory is customized to a particular job or job family, it does not produce a uniform, cross-job-comparable output from a single instrument — directly contradicting the organization's goal of using one unchanged tool across all roles.
option_explanations.B: Functional Job Analysis rates worker involvement with data, people, and things on defined functional levels and does allow some cross-job comparison. However, FJA uses a hierarchical functional scale rather than pre-written behavioral statements rated on applicability and importance, and it does not organize content into the six descriptive categories — information input, cognitive operations, physical output, interpersonal relationships, job context, and miscellaneous characteristics — that are the identifying structural feature of the described instrument.
option_explanations.C: The Position Analysis Questionnaire is correct. The vignette describes pre-written behavioral statements covering how workers receive information, what they mentally process, what they physically produce, their interpersonal relationships, and their working conditions — the six PAQ divisions — rated on applicability and importance scales. The specific complaint that the instrument seems better suited to office settings and is hard for lower-skill workers to complete is a documented, well-known limitation of the PAQ tied to its college-level reading demand. The compensation use case based on uniform numerical output also matches the PAQ's primary applied application.
option_explanations.D: The Common Metric Questionnaire is the most dangerous distractor because it is also a worker-oriented, cross-job-comparable instrument using pre-written behavioral items rated on multiple scales, and it was explicitly developed to address the PAQ's readability problems. However, the CMQ was designed to reduce — not perpetuate — the difficulty lower-skill workers have with the instrument. The vignette explicitly describes workers struggling with the reading demands and items seeming abstract for lower-skill roles, which is a known limitation of the PAQ rather than the CMQ, making the PAQ the more precise fit.

questions.source_summary: To ensure a selection test has adequate reliability, Dr. Wong will administer it to a sample of legal assistants to determine if the test produces consistent scores.
questions.vignette: Dr. Wong is developing a new selection test for a law firm's hiring process. Before using the test operationally, she wants to confirm the instrument produces consistent scores across administrations. She administers the test to a sample of current legal assistants on two separate occasions, two weeks apart, and then correlates the two sets of scores. Her primary goal is to establish that the selection test yields stable, dependable results before using it to make hiring decisions.
questions.question: Which psychometric property is Dr. Wong most directly evaluating by administering the test twice and correlating the scores?

options.A: Criterion validity
options.B: Test-retest reliability
options.C: Content validity
options.D: Inter-rater reliability

option_explanations.A: Criterion validity refers to the degree to which test scores correlate with an external criterion measure (e.g., job performance ratings). Dr. Wong is not comparing test scores to any criterion — she is comparing two administrations of the same test to assess score consistency.
option_explanations.B: Test-retest reliability is the correct answer. It is assessed by administering the same instrument to the same group at two points in time and correlating the scores. Dr. Wong's procedure — two administrations separated by two weeks followed by a correlation — is the textbook definition of this reliability method.
option_explanations.C: Content validity evaluates whether the items on a test adequately represent the domain of knowledge or skills being measured. This is typically established through expert review or job analysis, not through repeated administration and correlation of scores.
option_explanations.D: Inter-rater reliability assesses consistency between two or more raters or scorers evaluating the same performance. It is relevant when subjective human judgment is involved in scoring, not in the context of administering the same objective test twice to the same sample.

questions.source_summary: To ensure a selection test has adequate reliability, Dr. Wong will administer it to a sample of legal assistants to determine if the test produces consistent scores.
questions.vignette: A large law firm is planning to expand its legal assistant workforce and has contracted an I/O psychologist to evaluate a newly developed cognitive ability assessment. The psychologist notes that many applicants are recent college graduates with limited work histories, making it difficult to gather sufficient criterion data at this stage. To address a more immediate concern, she administers the selection instrument to 60 current legal assistants, waits three weeks, and then has the same employees complete the instrument again. She then computes the correlation between the two sets of scores to determine whether the assessment is suitable for use in hiring.
questions.question: What is the psychologist primarily attempting to establish about the cognitive ability assessment?

options.A: Predictive validity
options.B: Internal consistency
options.C: Test-retest reliability
options.D: Concurrent validity

option_explanations.A: Predictive validity is a form of criterion validity in which test scores are correlated with criterion measures collected in the future (e.g., performance reviews six months post-hire). The psychologist explicitly notes that criterion data are unavailable right now, and her procedure involves two test administrations rather than a test-to-criterion correlation.
option_explanations.B: Internal consistency reliability (e.g., Cronbach's alpha) evaluates whether items within a single test administration measure the same construct by examining inter-item correlations. The psychologist administered the test on two separate occasions — a procedure that does not assess internal consistency.
option_explanations.C: Test-retest reliability is the correct answer. The procedure of administering the same instrument to the same group at two time points and correlating the scores directly operationalizes test-retest reliability. This approach assesses score stability over time, which is what the psychologist is evaluating before deploying the instrument in hiring.
option_explanations.D: Concurrent validity is established by correlating test scores with criterion measures obtained at the same time (e.g., comparing test scores with current performance ratings of incumbents). The psychologist's design involves two test administrations with no criterion measure, distinguishing it from any validity study.

questions.source_summary: To ensure a selection test has adequate reliability, Dr. Wong will administer it to a sample of legal assistants to determine if the test produces consistent scores.
questions.vignette: An I/O psychologist at a staffing agency is tasked with evaluating a situational judgment test (SJT) intended for use in selecting legal assistants. The agency director mentions that several candidates performed very differently on the SJT during a pilot compared to their scores on a validated work sample administered on the same day, raising concerns about the instrument. However, the psychologist decides to set aside the comparison to the work sample for now. Instead, she recruits 75 incumbent legal assistants, administers the SJT to them, waits three weeks, and re-administers the SJT, computing a correlation between the two sets of results to determine whether the instrument demonstrates consistency of measurement over time.
questions.question: The agency director's concern about SJT scores differing from work sample scores is a red herring. What psychometric property is the psychologist actually investigating with her two-administration design?

options.A: Concurrent validity
options.B: Test-retest reliability
options.C: Alternate-forms reliability
options.D: Predictive validity

option_explanations.A: Concurrent validity would be investigated by correlating SJT scores with criterion scores (e.g., supervisor ratings or the work sample scores) collected at the same point in time. The director's concern about divergence from the work sample score does involve simultaneous data collection, making this a plausible distractor — but the psychologist explicitly sets aside that comparison and uses a two-occasion, same-instrument design with no criterion measure.
option_explanations.B: Test-retest reliability is the correct answer. The psychologist administers the identical SJT to the same incumbents at two time points and correlates the scores to evaluate temporal stability of measurement. This is the defining procedure for test-retest reliability, and consistency over time is the stated goal.
option_explanations.C: Alternate-forms reliability (also called parallel-forms reliability) is assessed by correlating scores from two different versions of the same test administered to the same group. The vignette describes a single SJT being administered twice — there is only one form of the instrument — so this method does not apply.
option_explanations.D: Predictive validity involves correlating scores obtained at one point in time with criterion measures (e.g., performance ratings) collected at a later point. Although the vignette has a temporal gap between administrations, both data points are test scores, not a test score and a performance criterion, ruling out predictive validity.

questions.source_summary: To ensure a selection test has adequate reliability, Dr. Wong will administer it to a sample of legal assistants to determine if the test produces consistent scores.
questions.vignette: Dr. Reyes is evaluating a newly developed biodata questionnaire intended to screen applicants for legal assistant positions at a mid-sized law firm. The managing partner had originally hoped to compare biodata scores with supervisors' current performance appraisals to determine whether the instrument measures what it is supposed to measure, but performance appraisal data are riddled with halo effects and are unavailable for half the incumbents. Undeterred, Dr. Reyes recruits 80 current legal assistants, administers the biodata instrument, and three weeks later administers the same biodata instrument again. She notes that biodata items often tap biographical facts that should not change over such a short interval, a feature she leverages to make inferences about the stability of the scores. She computes a single correlation coefficient summarizing the relationship between the two administrations.
questions.question: The managing partner's plan to use appraisal data makes concurrent validity appear to be the central concern, but Dr. Reyes ultimately pursues a different objective. Which psychometric property does her two-administration correlation most directly evaluate?

options.A: Concurrent validity
options.B: Internal consistency reliability
options.C: Test-retest reliability
options.D: Construct validity

option_explanations.A: Concurrent validity is established by correlating predictor scores with criterion scores (e.g., performance appraisals) obtained at essentially the same time. The managing partner's original plan would have investigated concurrent validity, making this the primary red herring. However, Dr. Reyes explicitly abandons that plan and conducts no criterion comparison, rendering concurrent validity inapplicable to her actual procedure.
option_explanations.B: Internal consistency reliability (e.g., Cronbach's alpha, split-half reliability) is determined from a single administration by examining the degree to which items within the test intercorrelate. Dr. Reyes administers the biodata instrument on two separate occasions and computes a correlation across those occasions — a two-administration design that is definitionally inconsistent with internal consistency methods.
option_explanations.C: Test-retest reliability is the correct answer. Dr. Reyes administers the same instrument to the same sample at two time points separated by three weeks and correlates the results to assess temporal stability — the defining procedure for test-retest reliability. Her observation that biodata items reflect stable biographical facts directly supports the logic of test-retest reliability, where true scores should remain constant over short intervals.
option_explanations.D: Construct validity is a broad psychometric property referring to whether a test measures the theoretical construct it purports to measure, typically established through a convergent and discriminant evidence program or factor analysis. Dr. Reyes does not compare the biodata instrument to conceptually related or unrelated measures, nor does she conduct factor-analytic work — she simply re-administers the same instrument and correlates scores.

questions.source_summary: To ensure a selection test has adequate reliability, Dr. Wong will administer it to a sample of legal assistants to determine if the test produces consistent scores.
questions.vignette: A law firm's human resources department has acquired a new paper-based screening tool designed to rank job candidates for an administrative support role. Because the firm's most recent performance records are several years out of date and deemed unsuitable for comparison, the HR director decides to withhold them entirely. She instead recruits 70 people currently working in that administrative role, hands each of them the questionnaire on a Tuesday morning, collects the completed forms, and then — three weeks later, on a Tuesday morning — hands each of the same 70 employees the identical questionnaire again under the same conditions. She observes that the questionnaire contains items about preferences and habits that would not reasonably be expected to shift over such a short time. After collecting the second set of forms, she computes a single numerical index describing how closely each person's first set of answers matched their second set and concludes that the tool produces sufficiently stable results to be used with confidence.
questions.question: What psychometric property has the HR director evaluated through this procedure?

options.A: Concurrent validity
options.B: Test-retest reliability
options.C: Alternate-forms reliability
options.D: Internal consistency reliability

option_explanations.A: Concurrent validity would require the HR director to compare scores on the questionnaire with a separate criterion measure — such as supervisor ratings or performance records — collected at roughly the same time. The deliberate exclusion of the performance records is designed to make this option tempting, because the vignette explains why criterion data were set aside. However, no criterion measure is involved in her actual procedure; she only administers the questionnaire twice and correlates the two sets of scores.
option_explanations.B: Test-retest reliability is the correct answer. The hallmark features are all present: the same instrument administered to the same group on two occasions separated by a fixed interval (three weeks), under identical conditions, with a correlation (the 'single numerical index') computed between the two administrations. The HR director's observation that the items should not change over three weeks reflects the core logic of test-retest reliability — that true score variance should remain stable across occasions, and any inconsistency reflects measurement error.
option_explanations.C: Alternate-forms reliability is assessed by administering two different but equivalent versions of the same instrument to the same group and correlating the results. The vignette specifies that the HR director hands employees 'the identical questionnaire' both times — there is only one form — making alternate-forms reliability definitionally inapplicable, even though the two-occasion structure superficially resembles that design.
option_explanations.D: Internal consistency reliability is determined from a single administration by analyzing the extent to which items within that administration intercorrelate (e.g., via Cronbach's alpha or a split-half procedure). The HR director conducts two separate administrations and generates a correlation across occasions rather than across items within one occasion, which is incompatible with internal consistency methodology, even though both yield a correlation coefficient.

questions.source_summary: To use the Taylor-Russell tables to estimate a predictor's incremental validity, one needs to know the predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient, the selection ratio, and the base rate.
questions.vignette: An HR consultant at a regional hospital is evaluating a new cognitive ability test intended to improve nurse hiring outcomes. She wants to estimate how much the test will improve the proportion of successful hires above what is currently achieved by chance. To do so, she plans to use the Taylor-Russell tables, which require her to know the criterion-related validity coefficient for the test, the selection ratio of applicants who are hired, and the base rate of employees who succeed without any formal testing. With these three inputs, she can estimate the test's incremental utility.
questions.question: Which combination of three inputs does the HR consultant need to use the Taylor-Russell tables to estimate the predictor's incremental validity?

options.A: Criterion-related validity coefficient, selection ratio, and base rate
options.B: Criterion-related validity coefficient, test reliability, and base rate
options.C: Adverse impact ratio, selection ratio, and base rate
options.D: Criterion-related validity coefficient, selection ratio, and cost-per-hire

option_explanations.A: This is correct. The Taylor-Russell tables were specifically designed to estimate the proportion of successful employees when three values are known: the predictor's criterion-related validity, the selection ratio (proportion of applicants hired), and the base rate (proportion who would succeed without the test).
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. Test reliability is an important psychometric property but is not one of the three inputs required by the Taylor-Russell tables. Reliability is used to estimate a test's measurement precision, whereas the Taylor-Russell formula uses the validity coefficient, not a separate reliability figure.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. The adverse impact ratio is used to evaluate whether a selection procedure disproportionately excludes a protected group under EEOC guidelines (the 4/5ths rule), not to estimate incremental validity via the Taylor-Russell tables.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Cost-per-hire is relevant to utility analysis frameworks such as the Brogden-Cronbach-Gleser model, which incorporates economic variables. The Taylor-Russell tables do not require cost information; they focus on proportional success rates.

questions.source_summary: To use the Taylor-Russell tables to estimate a predictor's incremental validity, one needs to know the predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient, the selection ratio, and the base rate.
questions.vignette: A large logistics company is considering adopting a structured behavioral interview to screen warehouse supervisors. The HR team, composed mostly of individuals with backgrounds in finance rather than psychology, has assembled some test data but is unsure which statistics they actually need. A consultant notes that the current promotion rate for supervisors is unusually high due to a recent expansion, and she explains that even this 'noisy' period provides a meaningful estimate of how many candidates would succeed without any new assessment tool. She tells the team that to estimate incremental validity using a standard actuarial table in the selection literature, they will need that current success proportion, the fraction of applicants who receive offers, and one additional piece of information derived from validation research.
questions.question: Which three pieces of information does the consultant need to complete her estimate of the interview's incremental validity using the appropriate actuarial table?

options.A: The adverse impact ratio, the proportion of applicants hired, and the proportion of current employees who succeed
options.B: The criterion-related validity coefficient, the proportion of applicants hired, and the proportion of employees who would succeed without the test
options.C: The criterion-related validity coefficient, the test's internal consistency reliability, and the proportion of employees who would succeed without the test
options.D: The content validity ratio, the proportion of applicants hired, and the cost savings associated with improved hiring

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The Taylor-Russell tables require three inputs: the criterion-related validity coefficient (derived from validation research), the selection ratio (proportion of applicants hired), and the base rate (proportion of employees who would succeed without the predictor). The consultant's description maps directly onto these three values.
option_explanations.A: This is incorrect. The adverse impact ratio is used to evaluate disparate impact under the 4/5ths rule, not to estimate incremental validity. While the selection ratio and base rate are both needed, replacing the validity coefficient with the adverse impact ratio yields a different type of analysis entirely.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. Internal consistency reliability (e.g., Cronbach's alpha) describes how consistently a test measures a construct, but it is not a required input for the Taylor-Russell tables. These tables use the validity coefficient — the correlation between predictor scores and job performance — not the reliability of the predictor itself.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. Content validity ratio (CVR) is used in content validation studies (e.g., Lawshe's method) to determine whether test items are job-relevant. Cost savings are an input for utility analysis models such as Brogden-Cronbach-Gleser, not for the Taylor-Russell tables, which are entirely cost-free in their framework.

questions.source_summary: To use the Taylor-Russell tables to estimate a predictor's incremental validity, one needs to know the predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient, the selection ratio, and the base rate.
questions.vignette: A consultant is helping a mid-sized financial services firm decide whether to add a personality inventory to its analyst hiring process. The firm already hires about one in every five applicants and has good historical records showing that roughly 60% of hired analysts have been rated as high performers by their supervisors over the past decade. The personality inventory vendor provided a technical report showing that the inventory correlates meaningfully with supervisor performance ratings in comparable samples. The consultant explains that she can use a standardized actuarial lookup procedure to determine precisely what percentage of hired analysts would likely be high performers if the inventory were added to the selection system — without requiring any information about salary, training costs, or economic variables.
questions.question: What three pieces of information is the consultant using to complete this actuarial estimate of the inventory's incremental value?

options.A: The inventory's criterion-related validity coefficient, the proportion of applicants who are hired, and the historical proportion of successful employees
options.B: The inventory's construct validity evidence, the proportion of applicants who are hired, and the historical proportion of successful employees
options.C: The inventory's criterion-related validity coefficient, the applicant pool size, and the historical proportion of successful employees
options.D: The inventory's criterion-related validity coefficient, the proportion of applicants who are hired, and the standard deviation of job performance in dollar units

option_explanations.A: This is correct. The consultant is describing the Taylor-Russell tables, which require exactly three inputs: (1) the criterion-related validity coefficient from the vendor's technical report, (2) the selection ratio (one in five applicants hired), and (3) the base rate (60% historical success rate). The explicit exclusion of economic variables rules out utility analysis frameworks.
option_explanations.B: This is incorrect. Construct validity evidence (e.g., convergent and discriminant validity data) addresses whether a test measures the intended psychological construct, but is not an input to the Taylor-Russell tables. The tables specifically require criterion-related validity — the empirical correlation between predictor scores and job performance outcomes.
option_explanations.C: This is incorrect. The Taylor-Russell tables use the selection ratio (the proportion of applicants hired), not the raw applicant pool size. While the absolute number of applicants might be useful in other contexts (e.g., Brogden-Cronbach-Gleser utility analysis), the tables require a ratio, making this option subtly but importantly wrong.
option_explanations.D: This is incorrect. The standard deviation of job performance in dollar units (SDy) is a critical input for the Brogden-Cronbach-Gleser utility analysis model, which estimates the economic value of a selection procedure. The Taylor-Russell tables explicitly avoid economic variables and focus only on proportional success rates, making SDy irrelevant here.

questions.source_summary: To use the Taylor-Russell tables to estimate a predictor's incremental validity, one needs to know the predictor's criterion-related validity coefficient, the selection ratio, and the base rate.
questions.vignette: A staffing psychologist is advising a government agency that wants to quantify the improvement in hiring outcomes expected from a newly validated aptitude test. The agency has a well-documented history of job performance ratings across hundreds of employees hired over many years, allowing a stable estimate of how often employees meet performance standards under the current approach. The psychologist notes that the agency's recent hiring freeze means only a small fraction of applicants are currently being offered positions, and she explains that this low figure is actually advantageous for interpreting the test's expected impact. She emphasizes that her estimation method does not require the agency to assign any monetary value to employee performance, nor does it involve the test's internal psychometric structure — only its relationship to measured job outcomes matters. Using a well-known tabular method from the selection literature, she determines that the expected proportion of successful hires would rise substantially if the test were adopted.
questions.question: Which method is the psychologist using, and what are the three required inputs?

options.A: Brogden-Cronbach-Gleser utility analysis, requiring the validity coefficient, selection ratio, and SDy
options.B: Taylor-Russell tables, requiring the criterion-related validity coefficient, selection ratio, and base rate
options.C: Expectancy chart analysis, requiring the validity coefficient, test score distribution, and base rate
options.D: Lawshe utility analysis, requiring the content validity ratio, selection ratio, and base rate

option_explanations.B: This is correct. The psychologist's description precisely maps onto the Taylor-Russell tables: a tabular method that uses the criterion-related validity coefficient, the selection ratio (the fraction of applicants hired — noted as low due to the hiring freeze), and the base rate (the historical proportion of successful employees).
